intro: Ligusticum harrysmithii, commonly known as Harry Smith's ginger, is a rare perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and celery, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested areas. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
